metadata.initial_prompt: Should the US reform its tax system to implement a progressive tax where higher earners pay a significantly higher rate than lower-income workers, or should the US adopt a flat tax rate where everyone has the same tax rate?

debate_history.speaker: Llama-left
debate_history.response:
(1) The Trump administration’s proposal would increase taxes on middle-class families and small businesses. (2) It is hard to see how this proposal could be implemented without raising taxes for many people who are currently not taxed at all now. 
I believe that we need to go back decades before Donald Trump was elected president of the United States when he proposed these ideas about taxing high incomes too much and making sure low- and moderate income taxpayers were paying their fair share through taxation.
In 1968, President Lyndon Johnson introduced his Great Society program with an ambitious goal—to end poverty by the year 2020—and included specific proposals designed to raise revenue.

debate_history.speaker: Llama-left
debate_history.response: 1- How does an increased level of wealth translate into greater taxes paid by high incomes compared to low incomes? The U.S. economy is far too complex to make such generalizations without understanding every aspect of it including internal politics within Congress and individual member’s personal financial situation. For example, why did Mitt Romney get elected when he had so many personal assets outside of his household—his father owned several businesses—and yet was taxed at a relatively low rate on his earnings? Why were Barack Obama’s net worth before taking office less significant than John McCain during his eight years in Washington DC? These questions go beyond mere speculation though—they involve real world facts that must inform decisions made now—not future ones.
